document.masterDocTitle: A review of the Munidopsidae Ortmann, 1898 (Decapoda, Galatheoidea) in Chilean waters, including new records for the Southeastern Pacific

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the Munidopsidae Ortmann, 1898 (Decapoda, Galatheoidea) in Chilean waters, including new records for the Southeastern Pacific

Henderson, 1888

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8.
Munidopsis quadrata Faxon, 1893
, male cl 9.30 mm, MUAP(CD)-04111: a, lateral view of carapace; b, lateral view of abdomen; c, right cheliped; d, third right pereiopod; e, detail of carpus of right cheliped; f, merus of right cheliped. Scale = 1 mm.

FIGURE 9.
Munidopsis subsquamosa Henderson, 1888
, ovigerous female cl 18.28 mm, MUAP(CD)-0468: a, anterior region of carapace; b, lateral view of carapace; c, lateral view of abdomen; d, left cheliped; e, carpus and merus of left cheliped; f, third left pereiopod; g, dactyl of third pereiopod; h, detail of ventrodistal spine of propodus of third pereiopod. Scale = 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality
. Stn 237 expedition “Challenger” off the Japanese coast, SE of Nojimazaki, Boso Peninsula, Japan (
34 ° 37 ’N
,
140 ° 32 ’E
), 3431 m .

New record . MUAP (CD)-0468, ovigerous female, cl 18.28 mm , off Caldera (~ 27 °S; about 1000 m ),
February 2004
, taken in Patagonian Toothfish (
Dissostichus eleginoides
) long-line at about 1000 m ; MUAP (CD)-0469, ovigerous female cl 17.56 mm , off Concepción “ONR” expedition AGT 0 7 (
32 ° 21.64 ’S
,
73 ° 43.57 ’W
, 865–926 m ).

Description . Rostrum acute, short, almost half carapace length; with medial keel. Carapace almost pentagonal, densely covered by scale-like tubercles ending in minute spine with row of single setae; few spines in cardiac region and along margins (see Henderson 1895 ); antennal spine acute, short, not reaching the cornea; carapace surface flat, without well delimited regions; cervical groove poorly developed (
Fig. 9
b). Eyes with long ocular spine (
Fig. 9
a). Abdominal segments unarmed, with 1 transverse groove on second to fourth somites (
Fig. 9
c). Chelipeds short, almost same length as carapace; palm as long as dactyl, both unarmed (
Fig. 9
d), surface with low tubercles ending in row of setae; carpus and merus armed with strong spines on the distal margin, merus with mesial row of spines (
Fig. 9
e). Walking legs as long as two-thirds total length carapace, armed on the dorsal margin of carpus and merus; propodus and dactyl unarmed dorsally (
Fig. 9
f); dactyl with ventral row of spines, each with seta on anterior margin (
Fig. 9
g); distoventral end of propodus with mobile spine (
Fig. 9
f, h).

Remarks . The main differences between the syntype of
M. subsquamosa aculeata Faxon
and the lectotype of
M. subsquamosa Henderson
compared to the specimens analyzed here are in the straighter dactyls of the P 2–4 (
Fig. 9
g). Regarding the differences noted by
Baba ( 2005 )
in the more spinous form of the syntype specimens than the lectotype of
M. subsquamosa
, the specimens observed here are scarcely spinous and the rostrum is upturned. By this, our specimens are more similar to
M. subsquamosa aculeata
. Nevertheless, the differences are not sufficient to separate then into two subspecies, as also concluded by
Baba ( 2005 )
.

Munidopsis subsquamosa
has been cited many times in Chilean waters as
M. aculeata
Henderson, 1888
,
M. subsquamosa
var. aculeata
Henderson, 1888
, or
M. subsquamosa aculeata
Faxon, 1895
(
Haig 1955
;
Retamal 1981
,
2000
;
Retamal & Moyano 2011
). Despite these citations, specimens of this species were known from Chile only from the original description, so this is a new record of the species.
